div1.p: Great Frenchman Once Lived in Waverly

div1.head: Newspaper clipping, [19--]
div1.p:
GREAT FRENCHMAN ONCE LIVED
IN WAVERLY.

Henry Augustus Adrian, during his
lecture at Chautauqua last Friday af-
ternoon spoke of great men of differ-
ent countries, men who did more for
humanity than did great soldiers who
directed armies from a safe distance
behind the firing line, and he gave
names of many men who deserve
more credit and honor than do states-
men or warriors. Among these he
mentioned the name of a French doc-
tor who gave his life in research
to discover the cause of yellow fever
and to find a remedy to combat the
disease. He went into the swamps of
the islands of the Carribeban sea,
where the readly mosquitoes bred,
and with their death germs carried
disease to human beings, and there he
prosecuted his research work for the
good of mankind, discovering causes
and remedies which have saved many
thousands of lives. Through this
work the great doctor lost his life,
dying in Havana, Cuba, while experi-
menting with yellow fever germs, and
in many large cities monuments have
been erected to his memory. The
speaker stated that Dr. Lezear was a
greater man than Napoleon; a great-
er man even than Dr. Pasteur, whose
fame is world-wide; in fact, Lazear
was the greatest man that France has
ever known.

That great man was Jesse W. La-
zear, who, as a boy lived in Waverly,
and with G. O. VanDerveer and Julian
Ruddick, worked in the German-
American Savings Bank in this city.
He was a nephew of Mr. and Mrs. R.
W. Sweitzer, the gentleman being at
that time cashier of the bank.

Young Lazear was of French par-
entage and came to this country to
study medicine at the John Hopkins
University, and during his vacation
time he came to Waverly to visit and
was a guest in the J. H. Bowman
home, and found employment in the
bank, of which Mr. Bowman was then
president. After completing his edu-
cation in America, he returned to
France and took a course in research
work. In the late 80's he again came
to this country and became a citizen
of the United States. With the out-
break of the Spanish-American war,
he went to Cuba, and there, with
other physicians connected with the
army, he began his research work to
discover the cause of yellow fever.
Many experiments were made with
the insects, which were permitted to
bite volunteers, and among these vol-
unteers was Dr. Lazear. At first, al-
though others were stricken with the
deadly disease, it did not manifest
itself in his case. However, on Sep-
tember 13, 1900, he was bitten by a
mosquito in a hospital in Havana,
where yellow fever patients were be-
ing treated. Five days later he came
down with a chill, and on the 25th of
the same month he died. He had ac-
complished his purpose before death
claimed him. His theory that the
disease was caused by mosquitoes
was proven, and he sacrificed his life
for the sake of humanity.

Mr. Adrian, when he delivered his
address, did not know that this cele-
brated doctor had once lived here, or
he would have used the fact in his
lecture. Many of our citizens will
remember Jesse Lazear as a bank
clerk, and this item will be of inter-
est to them.
